did.head: Descriptive Summary

physdesc.label: Extent
physdesc.extent: 156 manuscript boxes, 26 card file boxes, 5 oversize boxes, 10 envelopes, 5 microfilm reels, 7 phonotapes, memorabilia

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, printed matter, and audio-visual material, relating to Russian literature and culture both in the Soviet Union and the emigration, political conditions in the Soviet Union, Soviet dissidents, and the Russian emigre community. Includes correspondence and writings of Nikolai Gumilev, Marina Tsvetaeva and other Russian writers. Available on microfilm (265 reels). Digital copies of selected items also available.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p:
Closed. Microfilm use copies available.
The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Gleb Struve papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1985.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born, St. Petersburg, Russia. Son of Petr Berngardovich Struve
Serves in the Volunteer (White) Army. Spends three months as hostage in the Novorossiisk city prison
Escapes to Finland and later emigrates to England
B.A., Balliol College, Oxford
Engages in journalism in Germany and then France. Contributes mainly to Russian emigre newspapers in Paris including Vozrozhdenie, Rossiia and Rossiia i Slavianstvo
Lecturer and later Reader in Russian Literature, University of London
Translator, Ivan Bunin, The Well of Days
Author, Soviet Russian Literature. Revised and enlarged editions appear under somewhat different titles in 1944, 1951 and 1971. Translated into French, 1946; German, 1958 and 1964; Italian, 1975
Author (with E.A. Moore), Practical Russian
Visiting Lecturer, University of California, Berkeley
Professor of Slavic Languages and Literatures, University of California, Berkeley

eventgrp.event: Author, Russkii evropeets: materialy dlia biografii i kharakteristiki kniazia P.B. Kozlovskogo
Translator (with Mary Kriger), George Orwell's Animal Farm. Reissued in 1967 and 1971
Editor (with G. A. Birkett), Anton Chekhov, Selected Short Stories
Editor, Neizdannyi Gumilev: "Otravlennaia tunika" i drugie neizdannye proizvedeniia

chronitem.event: Author, Russkaia literatura v izgnanii: opyt istoricheskogo obzora russkoi zarubezhnoi literatury. Second edition, 1984
Author, Geschichte der Sowjetliteratur
Editor, N. Gumilev, Sobranie sochinenii
Editor, Osip Mandel'shtam. Sobranie sochinenii v dvukh tomakh. Second edition, 1981

eventgrp.event: Editor, Anna Akhmatova, Sochineniia. Second edition, 1967
Author, A Century of Russian Prose and Verse
Author, Utloe zhil'e: Izbrannye stikhi 1915-1949. Second edition, 1978

chronitem.event: Hon. LLD., University of Toronto
Editor, Marina Tsvetaeva, Neizdannye pis'ma
Recipient, Berkeley Citation
Author, K istorii russkoi poezii 1910kh--nachala 1920kh godov
Author, O chetyrekh poetakh
Editor, Maksimilian Voloshin, Stikhotvoreniia i poemy v dvukh tomakh
Dies, Berkeley, California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, speeches and writings, printed matter, and audio-visual material, relating to Russian literature and culture both in the Soviet Union and the emigration, political conditions in the Soviet Union, Soviet dissidents, and the Russian emigre community. Includes correspondence and writings of Nikolai Gumilev, Marina Tsvetaeva and other Russian writers. Also available on microfilm (265 reels).

item.extref: Downloadable PDF file of the Microfilm Reel Content Guide

scopecontent.p: Biographical material, including personal documents, papers relating to his family and clippings. Arranged by subject.
